Embeddability of right-angled Artin groups on the complements of linear forests

Takuya Katayama (Takuya Katayama) Department of Mathematics, Hiroshima University, 1-3-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, Hiroshima 739-8526, Japan tkatayama@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
Abstract.

In this article, we prove that embeddings of right-angled Artin group A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} on the complement of a linear forest into another right-angled Artin group A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} can be reduced to full embeddings of the defining graph of A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} into the extension graph of the defining graph of A2subscript𝐴2A_{2}.

Key words and phrases:
Right-angled Artin group
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary: 20F36

1. Introduction

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a simple graph (abbreviated a graph). We denote the vertex set and the edge set of ΓΓ\Gamma by V​(Γ)𝑉ΓV(\Gamma) and E​(Γ)𝐸ΓE(\Gamma), respectively. The right-angled Artin group on ΓΓ\Gamma is the group given by the following presentation:

A​(Γ)=⟨V​(Γ)∣vi​vj​vi−1​vj−1=1​if​{vi,vj}∈E​(Γ)⟩.𝐴Γinner-product𝑉Γsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑗11ifsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗𝐸ΓA(\Gamma)=\langle V(\Gamma)\mid\ v_{i}v_{j}v_{i}^{-1}v_{j}^{-1}=1\ \mbox{if}\ \{v_{i},v_{j}\}\in E(\Gamma)\ \rangle.

A graph homomorphism is a map between the vertex sets of two graphs, which maps adjacent vertices to adjacent vertices. An injective graph homomorphism (abbreviated an embedding) ι:Λ→Γ:𝜄→ΛΓ\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma is called full if ι𝜄\iota maps non-adjacent vertices to non-adjacent vertices. If there is a full embedding ι:Λ→Γ:𝜄→ΛΓ\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma, then we denote by Λ≤ΓΛΓ\Lambda\leq\Gamma and ΛΛ\Lambda is called a full subgraph of ΓΓ\Gamma. For finite graphs ΛΛ\Lambda and ΓΓ\Gamma, it is well-known that A​(Λ)𝐴ΛA(\Lambda) is isomorphic to A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) as a group if and only if ΛΛ\Lambda is isomorphic to ΓΓ\Gamma as a graph. Following S. Kim and T. Koberda [4], the extension graph ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e} of a finite graph ΓΓ\Gamma is the graph such that the vertex set of ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e} consists of the words in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) that are conjugate to the vertices of ΓΓ\Gamma, and two vertices of ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e} are joined by an edge if and only if they are commutative as words in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma). A celebrated theorem due to Kim–Koberda states that, if a finite graph ΛΛ\Lambda is a full subgraph of the extension graph ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e} of a finite graph ΓΓ\Gamma, then we have an injective homomorphism (abbreviated an embedding) A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma). In this article, a path graph Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} on n(≥1)annotated𝑛absent1n\ (\geq 1) vertices is the graph whose underlying space is homeomorphic to the origin {0}0\{0\} or unit interval [0,1]01[0,1] in the 111-dimensional Euclidean space. A linear forest is the disjoint union of finitely many path graphs. The complement ΛcsuperscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda^{c} of a graph ΛΛ\Lambda is the graph consisting of the vertex set V​(Λc)=V​(Λ)𝑉superscriptΛ𝑐𝑉ΛV(\Lambda^{c})=V(\Lambda) and the edge set E​(Λc)={{u,v}∣u,v∈V​(Λ),{u,v}∉E​(Λ)}𝐸superscriptΛ𝑐conditional-set𝑢𝑣formulae-sequence𝑢𝑣𝑉Λ𝑢𝑣𝐸ΛE(\Lambda^{c})=\{\{u,v\}\mid u,v\in V(\Lambda),\ \{u,v\}\notin E(\Lambda)\}.

In [3] the author “proved” the following theorem.

Theorem 1.1.

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the complement of a linear forest and ΓΓ\Gamma a finite graph. If A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Λ≤ΓΛΓ\Lambda\leq\Gamma.

We remark that Theorem 1.1 is equivalent to [3, Theorem 1.3(1)]. In the proof of [3, Theorem 1.3(1)], the author used the following “Theorem” (see the second line of the proof of Theorem 3.6 in [3]).

Theorem 1.2 ([1, Theorem 3.14]).

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the complement of a forest and ΓΓ\Gamma a finite graph. If A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Λ≤ΓeΛsuperscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}.

However, E. Lee and S. Lee [5] pointed out that the above “Theorem” is incorrect by giving a counter-example. Thus the author’s proof of Theorem 1.1 in [3] is not valid.

The purpose of this article is to give a complete proof of Theorem 1.1 by establishing the following theorem which shows that “Theorem 1.2” holds when ΛΛ\Lambda is the complement of a linear forest.

Theorem 1.3.

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the complement of a linear forest and ΓΓ\Gamma a finite graph. If A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Λ≤ΓeΛsuperscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}.

In fact, the author applied “Theorem 1.2” only for the complement of linear forests in the proof of Theorem 1.3(1) in [3].

We note that this theorem gives a partial positive answer to the following question.

Question 1.4 ([4, Question 1.5]).

For which graphs ΛΛ\Lambda and ΓΓ\Gamma do we have A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) only if Λ≤ΓeΛsuperscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}?

With regard to this question, the reader is referred to the introduction of the paper [5, Question 1.5] due to Lee–Lee.

This article is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce terminology and known results. For the sake of convenience, we discuss relation between graph-join (a certain graph operation) and embedding problems in Section 3. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of Theorem 1.3.

Acknowledgements

The author would like to thank his supervisor, Makoto Sakuma, for helpful discussions and a number of improvements regarding this paper. The author thanks to Eon-kyung Lee and Sang-jin Lee for their encouragements.

2. Preliminaries

Suppose that ΓΓ\Gamma is a graph. An element of V​(Γ)∪V​(Γ)−1𝑉Γ𝑉superscriptΓ1V(\Gamma)\cup V(\Gamma)^{-1} is called a letter. Any element in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) can be expressed as a word, which is a finite multiplication of letters. Let w=a1​⋯​al𝑤subscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑙w=a_{1}\cdots a_{l} be a word in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) where a1,…,alsubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑙a_{1},\ldots,a_{l} are letters. We say w𝑤w is reduced if any other word representing the same element as w𝑤w in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) has at least l𝑙l letters. The following lemma is useful for checking whether a given word is reduced or not (cf. [2, Section 5]).

Lemma 2.1.

Let w𝑤w be a word in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma). Then w𝑤w is reduced if and only if w𝑤w does not contain a word of the form vϵ​x​v−ϵsuperscript𝑣italic-ϵ𝑥superscript𝑣italic-ϵv^{\epsilon}xv^{-\epsilon}, where v𝑣v is a vertex of ΓΓ\Gamma, ϵ=±1italic-ϵplus-or-minus1\epsilon=\pm 1 and x𝑥x is a word such that v𝑣v is commutative with all of the letters in x𝑥x.

The support of a reduced word w𝑤w is the smallest subset S𝑆S of V​(Γ)𝑉ΓV(\Gamma) such that each letter of w𝑤w is in S𝑆S or S−1superscript𝑆1S^{-1}; we write S=supp​(w)𝑆supp𝑤S=\mathrm{supp}(w). It is well-known that the support does not depend on the choice of a reduced word, and so we can define the support of an element of A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma). By a clique, we mean a complete subgraph of a graph. We rephrase a special case of Servatius’ Centralizer Theorem [6, The Centralizer Theorem in Section III] as follows.

Lemma 2.2.

Let w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} and w2subscript𝑤2w_{2} be reduced words in A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) whose supports span cliques in ΓΓ\Gamma. Then the words w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} and w2subscript𝑤2w_{2} are commutative if and only if supp​(w1)suppsubscript𝑤1\mathrm{supp}(w_{1}) and supp​(w2)suppsubscript𝑤2\mathrm{supp}(w_{2}) are contained in a single clique in ΓΓ\Gamma.

In this article, we say that a homomorphism ψ:A​(Λ)→A​(Γ):𝜓→𝐴Λ𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\rightarrow A(\Gamma) between two right-angled Artin groups satisfies (KK) condition if supp​(ψ​(v))supp𝜓𝑣\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) consists of mutually adjacent vertices in ΓΓ\Gamma for all v∈V​(Λ)𝑣𝑉Λv\in V(\Lambda) (i.e., supp​(ψ​(v))supp𝜓𝑣\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) spans a clique in ΓΓ\Gamma).

Theorem 2.3 ([4, Theorem 4.3]).

Suppose that ΛΛ\Lambda and ΓΓ\Gamma are finite graphs and A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma). Then there is an embedding ψ:A​(Λ)↪A​(Γe):𝜓↪𝐴Λ𝐴superscriptΓ𝑒\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma^{e}) such that ψ𝜓\psi satisfies (KK) condition. Namely, for all v∈V​(Λ)𝑣𝑉Λv\in V(\Lambda), supp​(ψ​(v))supp𝜓𝑣\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)) consists of mutually adjacent vertices in ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e}.

3. Graph-join

In this section, we prove Proposition (2), which says that, for two finite graphs ΛΛ\Lambda and ΓΓ\Gamma such that there is an embedding A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) satisfying condition (KK), the problem of finding a full embedding Λ→Γ→ΛΓ\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma, with a certain restriction, is reduced to the corresponding problems for the “join-components” of ΛΛ\Lambda. The (graph-)join Λ1∗⋯∗ΛmsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} of graphs Λ1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} is the graph obtained from the disjoint union Λ1⊔⋯⊔Λmsquare-unionsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\Lambda_{m} by joining the vertices u𝑢u and v𝑣v for all u∈V​(Λi),v∈V​(Λj)formulae-sequence𝑢𝑉subscriptΛ𝑖𝑣𝑉subscriptΛ𝑗u\in V(\Lambda_{i}),v\in V(\Lambda_{j}) (i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j). In this article, we say that a graph ΛΛ\Lambda is irreducible (with respect to join) if ΛΛ\Lambda cannot be the join of two non-empty graphs. Any finite graph ΛΛ\Lambda is the join of finitely many irreducible graphs. Indeed, this follows from the fact that Λ=Λ1∗⋯∗ΛmΛsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda=\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} if and only if Λc=Λ1c⊔⋯⊔ΛmcsuperscriptΛ𝑐square-unionsuperscriptsubscriptΛ1𝑐⋯superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑚𝑐\Lambda^{c}=\Lambda_{1}^{c}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\Lambda_{m}^{c}. This fact also implies the following lemma.

Lemma 3.1.

A finite graph ΛΛ\Lambda is irreducible if and only if ΛcsuperscriptΛ𝑐\Lambda^{c} is connected. In particular, if ΛΛ\Lambda is an irreducible graph containing at least two vertices, then for any vertex u∈V​(Λ)𝑢𝑉Λu\in V(\Lambda), there is a vertex u′∈V​(Λ)superscript𝑢′𝑉Λu^{\prime}\in V(\Lambda) such that u𝑢u and u′superscript𝑢′u^{\prime} are non-adjacent.

Proof.

Suppose that ΛΛ\Lambda is an irreducible graph containing at least two vertices. Pick a vertex u∈V​(Λ)𝑢𝑉Λu\in V(\Lambda). If u𝑢u does not have a non-adjacent vertex, then we have a decomposition Λ={u}∗ΛˇΛ𝑢ˇΛ\Lambda=\{u\}*\check{\Lambda}, where ΛˇˇΛ\check{\Lambda} is a full subgraph spanned by V​(Λ)∖{u}𝑉Λ𝑢V(\Lambda)\setminus\{u\}, a contradiction. ∎

Besides, the right-angled Artin group on the join, A​(Λ1∗⋯∗Λm)𝐴subscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚A(\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m}), is isomorphic to the direct product A​(Λ1)×⋯×A​(Λm)𝐴subscriptΛ1⋯𝐴subscriptΛ𝑚A(\Lambda_{1})\times\dots\times A(\Lambda_{m}). For simplicity, if ψ:A​(Λ)→A​(Γ):𝜓→𝐴Λ𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\rightarrow A(\Gamma) is a homomorphism, then by supp​(ψ)supp𝜓\mathrm{supp}(\psi) we denote ∪v∈V​(Λ)supp​(ψ​(v))subscript𝑣𝑉Λsupp𝜓𝑣\cup_{v\in V(\Lambda)}\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)).

Proposition 3.2.

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the join Λ1∗⋯∗ΛmsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} of finite irreducible graphs Λ1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m}, and let ΓΓ\Gamma be a finite graph. Suppose that the following conditions hold:

  1. (1)

    There is an embedding ψ:A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ):𝜓↪𝐴Λ𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) satisfying condition (KK).

  2. (2)

    For each 1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m, there is a full embedding ιi:Λi→Γ:subscript𝜄𝑖→subscriptΛ𝑖Γ\iota_{i}\colon\Lambda_{i}\rightarrow\Gamma with ιi​(Λi)⊂supp​(ψi)subscript𝜄𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖suppsubscript𝜓𝑖\iota_{i}(\Lambda_{i})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{i}), where ψisubscript𝜓𝑖\psi_{i} is the restriction of ψ𝜓\psi to A​(Λi)𝐴subscriptΛ𝑖A(\Lambda_{i}).

Then there is a full embedding ι:Λ→Γ:𝜄→ΛΓ\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(Λ)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄Λsupp𝜓\iota(\Lambda)\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

We first prove this proposition in a special case.

Lemma 3.3.

Let Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} be a finite irreducible graph containing at least two vertices, and let Λ2subscriptΛ2\Lambda_{2} and ΓΓ\Gamma be finite graphs. Suppose that the following conditions hold:

  1. (1)

    There is an embedding ψ:A​(Λ1∗Λ2)↪A​(Γ):𝜓↪𝐴subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2})\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) satisfying condition (KK).

  2. (2)

    For i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2, there are full embeddings ιi:Λi→Γ:subscript𝜄𝑖→subscriptΛ𝑖Γ\iota_{i}\colon\Lambda_{i}\rightarrow\Gamma with ιi​(Λi)⊂supp​(ψi)subscript𝜄𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖suppsubscript𝜓𝑖\iota_{i}(\Lambda_{i})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{i}), where ψisubscript𝜓𝑖\psi_{i} is the restriction of ψ𝜓\psi to A​(Λi)𝐴subscriptΛ𝑖A(\Lambda_{i}).

Then the map ι:Λ1∗Λ2→Γ:𝜄→subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2Γ\iota\colon\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2}\rightarrow\Gamma, defined by ι​(v)=ι1​(v)𝜄𝑣subscript𝜄1𝑣\iota(v)=\iota_{1}(v) or ι2​(v)subscript𝜄2𝑣\iota_{2}(v) according to whether v∈V​(Λ1)𝑣𝑉subscriptΛ1v\in V(\Lambda_{1}) or v∈V​(Λ2)𝑣𝑉subscriptΛ2v\in V(\Lambda_{2}), is a full embedding with ι​(Λ1∗Λ2)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2supp𝜓\iota(\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

Proof.

We have only to prove: (i) ι1​(Λ1)∩ι2​(Λ2)=∅subscript𝜄1subscriptΛ1subscript𝜄2subscriptΛ2\iota_{1}(\Lambda_{1})\cap\iota_{2}(\Lambda_{2})=\emptyset and (ii) ∀u∈V​(Λ1),∀v∈V​(Λ2)formulae-sequencefor-all𝑢𝑉subscriptΛ1for-all𝑣𝑉subscriptΛ2\forall u\in V(\Lambda_{1}),\forall v\in V(\Lambda_{2}), ι1​(u)subscript𝜄1𝑢\iota_{1}(u) and ι2​(v)subscript𝜄2𝑣\iota_{2}(v) are adjacent in ΓΓ\Gamma. In fact (i) and (ii) imply that the map ι:Λ1∗Λ2→Γ:𝜄→subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2Γ\iota\colon\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2}\rightarrow\Gamma is a full embedding. Moreover, the assumptions ιi​(Λi)⊂supp​(ψi)subscript𝜄𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖suppsubscript𝜓𝑖\iota_{i}(\Lambda_{i})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{i}) imply that the full embedding ι𝜄\iota satisfies the desired property that ι​(Λ1∗Λ2)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2supp𝜓\iota(\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

(i) Pick u1∈V​(Λ1)subscript𝑢1𝑉subscriptΛ1u_{1}\in V(\Lambda_{1}) and u2∈V​(Λ2)subscript𝑢2𝑉subscriptΛ2u_{2}\in V(\Lambda_{2}). Since Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} is irreducible and has at least two vertices, Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} has a vertex u1′superscriptsubscript𝑢1′u_{1}^{\prime} which is non-adjacent to u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} in Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} by Lemma 3.1. Since u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} is not adjacent to u1′superscriptsubscript𝑢1′u_{1}^{\prime} in Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1}, and since ι1:Λ1→Γ:subscript𝜄1→subscriptΛ1Γ\iota_{1}\colon\Lambda_{1}\rightarrow\Gamma is full, ι1​(u1)subscript𝜄1subscript𝑢1\iota_{1}(u_{1}) is not adjacent to ι1​(u1′)subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime}) in ΓΓ\Gamma. On the other hand, we can prove that ι2​(u2)subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2\iota_{2}(u_{2}) is either identical with ι1​(u1′)subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime}) or adjacent to ι1​(u1′)subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime}) in ΓΓ\Gamma as follows (and so ι1​(u1)≠ι2​(u2)subscript𝜄1subscript𝑢1subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2\iota_{1}(u_{1})\neq\iota_{2}(u_{2}) in any case). By the assumptions that ιi​(Λi)⊂supp​(ψi)subscript𝜄𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖suppsubscript𝜓𝑖\iota_{i}(\Lambda_{i})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{i}) (i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2), there are vertices u¯1′∈V​(Λ1)superscriptsubscript¯𝑢1′𝑉subscriptΛ1\bar{u}_{1}^{\prime}\in V(\Lambda_{1}) and u¯2∈V​(Λ2)subscript¯𝑢2𝑉subscriptΛ2\bar{u}_{2}\in V(\Lambda_{2}) such that ι1​(u1′)∈supp​(ψ​(u¯1′))subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′supp𝜓superscriptsubscript¯𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime})\in\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{1}^{\prime})) and ι2​(u2)∈supp​(ψ​(u¯2))subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2supp𝜓subscript¯𝑢2\iota_{2}(u_{2})\in\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{2})). Moreover, since Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} and Λ2subscriptΛ2\Lambda_{2} are joined in Λ1∗Λ2subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2}, the image ψ​(u¯2)𝜓subscript¯𝑢2\psi(\bar{u}_{2}) is commutative with ψ​(u¯1′)𝜓superscriptsubscript¯𝑢1′\psi(\bar{u}_{1}^{\prime}), and therefore supp​(ψ​(u¯2))supp𝜓subscript¯𝑢2\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{2})) and supp​(ψ​(u¯1′))supp𝜓superscriptsubscript¯𝑢1′\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{1}^{\prime})) are contained in a single clique by (KK) condition and Lemma 2.2. Thus ι2​(u2)subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2\iota_{2}(u_{2}) is either adjacent to ι1​(u1′)subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime}) or identical with ι1​(u1′)subscript𝜄1superscriptsubscript𝑢1′\iota_{1}(u_{1}^{\prime}) in ΓΓ\Gamma.

(ii) Pick u1∈V​(Λ1)subscript𝑢1𝑉subscriptΛ1u_{1}\in V(\Lambda_{1}) and u2∈V​(Λ2)subscript𝑢2𝑉subscriptΛ2u_{2}\in V(\Lambda_{2}). There are vertices u¯1∈V​(Λ1)subscript¯𝑢1𝑉subscriptΛ1\bar{u}_{1}\in V(\Lambda_{1}) and u¯2∈V​(Λ2)subscript¯𝑢2𝑉subscriptΛ2\bar{u}_{2}\in V(\Lambda_{2}) such that ι1​(u1)∈supp​(ψ​(u¯1))subscript𝜄1subscript𝑢1supp𝜓subscript¯𝑢1\iota_{1}(u_{1})\in\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{1})) and ι2​(u2)∈supp​(ψ​(u¯2))subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2supp𝜓subscript¯𝑢2\iota_{2}(u_{2})\in\mathrm{supp}(\psi(\bar{u}_{2})). Since Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1} and Λ2subscriptΛ2\Lambda_{2} are joined in Λ1∗Λ2subscriptΛ1subscriptΛ2\Lambda_{1}*\Lambda_{2}, ψ​(u¯1)𝜓subscript¯𝑢1\psi(\bar{u}_{1}) and ψ​(u¯2)𝜓subscript¯𝑢2\psi(\bar{u}_{2}) are commutative. Hence, supp​(u¯1)suppsubscript¯𝑢1\mathrm{supp}(\bar{u}_{1}) and supp​(u¯2)suppsubscript¯𝑢2\mathrm{supp}(\bar{u}_{2}) are contained in a single clique in ΓΓ\Gamma by Lemma 2.2. Thus, ι1​(u1)subscript𝜄1subscript𝑢1\iota_{1}(u_{1}) and ι2​(u2)subscript𝜄2subscript𝑢2\iota_{2}(u_{2}) are adjacent in ΓΓ\Gamma. ∎

By Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}, we denote the complete graph on n𝑛n vertices. The right-angled Artin group on Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}, A​(Kn)𝐴subscript𝐾𝑛A(K_{n}), is isomorphic to ℤnsuperscriptℤ𝑛\mathbb{Z}^{n}.

Lemma 3.4.

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a finite graph. Suppose that ψ:A​(Kn)→A​(Γ):𝜓→𝐴subscript𝐾𝑛𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(K_{n})\rightarrow A(\Gamma) is an embedding satisfying condition (KK). Then there is a full embedding ι:Kn→Γ:𝜄→subscript𝐾𝑛Γ\iota\colon K_{n}\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(Kn)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄subscript𝐾𝑛supp𝜓\iota(K_{n})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

Proof.

Since ψ𝜓\psi satisfies condition (KK) and since Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n} is complete, supp​(ψ)supp𝜓\mathrm{supp}(\psi) spans a clique on l𝑙l vertices of ΓΓ\Gamma by Lemma 2.2. Hence, we have an embedding A​(Kn)≅ℤn↪ℤl↪A​(Γ)𝐴subscript𝐾𝑛superscriptℤ𝑛↪superscriptℤ𝑙↪𝐴ΓA(K_{n})\cong\mathbb{Z}^{n}\hookrightarrow\mathbb{Z}^{l}\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma). This implies n≤l𝑛𝑙n\leq l, and so we obtain an injective map V​(Kn)→supp​(ψ)→𝑉subscript𝐾𝑛supp𝜓V(K_{n})\rightarrow\mathrm{supp}(\psi), which induces a full embedding ι:Kn→Γ:𝜄→subscript𝐾𝑛Γ\iota\colon K_{n}\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(Kn)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄subscript𝐾𝑛supp𝜓\iota(K_{n})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi). ∎

Proof of Proposition (2).

We may assume that each of Λ1,…​ΛnsubscriptΛ1…subscriptΛ𝑛\Lambda_{1},\ldots\Lambda_{n} is a singleton graph and each of Λn+1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ𝑛1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{n+1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} has at least two vertices. Put Λ0:=Λ1∗⋯∗ΛnassignsubscriptΛ0subscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑛\Lambda_{0}:=\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{n}. Then Λ0subscriptΛ0\Lambda_{0} is isomorphic to the complete graph on n𝑛n vertices, Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}. In addition, we can decompose ΛΛ\Lambda into Λ0∗(∗i=n+1mΛi)\Lambda_{0}*(*_{i=n+1}^{m}\Lambda_{i}). Hence, we have A​(Λ)=A​(Λ0)×A​(Λn+1)×⋯×A​(Λm)𝐴Λ𝐴subscriptΛ0𝐴subscriptΛ𝑛1⋯𝐴subscriptΛ𝑚A(\Lambda)=A(\Lambda_{0})\times A(\Lambda_{n+1})\times\cdots\times A(\Lambda_{m}). By restricting ψ𝜓\psi to the abelian factor A​(Λ0)𝐴subscriptΛ0A(\Lambda_{0}), we obtain an embedding ψ0:A​(Λ0)↪A​(Γ):subscript𝜓0↪𝐴subscriptΛ0𝐴Γ\psi_{0}\colon A(\Lambda_{0})\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) satisfying condition (KK). Therefore, by Lemma 3.4, we obtain a full embedding ι0:Λ0→Γ:subscript𝜄0→subscriptΛ0Γ\iota_{0}:\Lambda_{0}\rightarrow\Gamma with ι0​(Λ0)⊂supp​(ψ0)subscript𝜄0subscriptΛ0suppsubscript𝜓0\iota_{0}(\Lambda_{0})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{0}). Consider the family of full embeddings ι0,ιn+1,…,ιmsubscript𝜄0subscript𝜄𝑛1…subscript𝜄𝑚\iota_{0},\iota_{n+1},\ldots,\iota_{m}. Since each of Λn+1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ𝑛1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{n+1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} is irreducible and has at least two vertices, by repeatedly applying Lemma 3.3, we obtain the desired full embedding ι:Λ0∗Λn+1∗⋯∗Λm→Γ:𝜄→subscriptΛ0subscriptΛ𝑛1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚Γ\iota\colon\Lambda_{0}*\Lambda_{n+1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m}\rightarrow\Gamma. ∎

4. Proof of Theorem 1.3

In this section we prove Theorem 1.3. We first rephrase Theorem 1.3 in terms of join. Recall that (Λ1⊔⋯⊔Λm)c=Λ1c∗⋯∗Λmcsuperscriptsquare-unionsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚𝑐superscriptsubscriptΛ1𝑐⋯superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑚𝑐(\Lambda_{1}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\Lambda_{m})^{c}=\Lambda_{1}^{c}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m}^{c}. Hence, if ΛΛ\Lambda is the complement of a linear forest, namely, if ΛΛ\Lambda is the complement of the disjoin union of finitely many path graphs, then ΛΛ\Lambda is the join of the complements of finitely many path graphs.

Theorem 4.1 (rephrased).

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the join of the complements of finitely many path graphs and ΓΓ\Gamma a finite graph. If A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ)↪𝐴Λ𝐴ΓA(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma), then Λ≤ΓeΛsuperscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{e}.

To obtain a full embedding Λ→Γe→ΛsuperscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma^{e} in the assertion above, we consider the join-component, the complement Pncsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑐P_{n}^{c} of the path graph Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} on n𝑛n vertices.

By Claim 4.4, Wˇ1,…,Wˇn−1subscriptˇ𝑊1…subscriptˇ𝑊𝑛1\check{W}_{1},\ldots,\check{W}_{n-1} are commutative with Wnsubscript𝑊𝑛W_{n}, which is a representative of ψ​(vn)𝜓subscript𝑣𝑛\psi(v_{n}). To treat the case where n=3𝑛3n=3, we use the following lemma due to Kim–Koberda.

Lemma 4.5 ([4, Theorem 5.4]).

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be a finite graph whose right-angled Artin group A​(Λ)𝐴ΛA(\Lambda) has no center. Suppose that A​(Λ)𝐴ΛA(\Lambda) has an embedding into the direct product G1×G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1}\times G_{2} of (non-trivial) groups G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2}. If the natural projections A​(Λ)→Gi→𝐴Λsubscript𝐺𝑖A(\Lambda)\rightarrow G_{i} (i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2) have non-trivial kernels, then ΛΛ\Lambda contains a full subgraph isomorphic to the cyclic graph of length 444.

Lemma 4.6.

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a finite graph. Suppose that ψ:A​(P3c)→A​(Γ):𝜓→𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(P_{3}^{c})\rightarrow A(\Gamma). Then there is a full embedding ι:P3c→Γ:𝜄→superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐Γ\iota\colon P_{3}^{c}\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(P3c)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐supp𝜓\iota(P_{3}^{c})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

Proof.

For simplicity, we assume that supp​(ψ)=V​(Γ)supp𝜓𝑉Γ\mathrm{supp}(\psi)=V(\Gamma). Suppose, on the contrary, that

  • (A)

    P3csuperscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐P_{3}^{c} is not a full subgraph of ΓΓ\Gamma. Namely, P3subscript𝑃3P_{3} is not a full subgraph of ΓcsuperscriptΓ𝑐\Gamma^{c}.

We first prove that ΓcsuperscriptΓ𝑐\Gamma^{c} is the disjoint union of finitely many complete graphs. Let C𝐶C be a connected component of ΓcsuperscriptΓ𝑐\Gamma^{c}. If #​V​(C)≤2#𝑉𝐶2\#V(C)\leq 2, then the connectedness of C𝐶C obviously implies that C𝐶C is complete. So we may assume #​V​(C)≥3#𝑉𝐶3\#V(C)\geq 3. Pick two edges e1csuperscriptsubscript𝑒1𝑐e_{1}^{c} and e2csuperscriptsubscript𝑒2𝑐e_{2}^{c} of C≤Γc𝐶superscriptΓ𝑐C\leq\Gamma^{c} that share a vertex. Then, by our assumption (A), the set e1c∪e2csuperscriptsubscript𝑒1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑒2𝑐e_{1}^{c}\cup e_{2}^{c} of vertices spans a triangle in ΓcsuperscriptΓ𝑐\Gamma^{c}. In other words, the initial vertex and terminal vertex of any edge-path consisting of three vertices in C𝐶C is adjacent. By repeatedly using this fact, we can verify that, for any edge-path in C𝐶C, the initial vertex is adjacent to the terminal vertex. Therefore the connected component C𝐶C must be complete. Thus, ΓcsuperscriptΓ𝑐\Gamma^{c} is the disjoint union of finitely many complete graphs, and so ΓΓ\Gamma is the join of finitely many edgeless graphs. Hence, A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) is the direct product A1×⋯×Amsubscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m} of free groups A1,…,Amsubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑚A_{1},\ldots,A_{m}. Since A​(P3c)𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐A(P_{3}^{c}) is not free and since A1×⋯×Amsubscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m} contains an embedded A​(P3c)𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐A(P_{3}^{c}), the integer m𝑚m is greater than 111. We now regard A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) as the direct product (A1×⋯×Am−1)×Amsubscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚1subscript𝐴𝑚(A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m-1})\times A_{m} of two direct factors, A1×⋯×Am−1subscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚1A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m-1} and Amsubscript𝐴𝑚A_{m}. Let πm−1,πmsubscript𝜋𝑚1subscript𝜋𝑚\pi_{m-1},\pi_{m} denotes the projections A​(P3c)→A1×⋯×Am−1→𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐subscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚1A(P_{3}^{c})\rightarrow A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m-1} and A​(P3c)→Am→𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐subscript𝐴𝑚A(P_{3}^{c})\rightarrow A_{m}, respectively. Then since A​(P3c)𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐A(P_{3}^{c}) is not free, the projection ker​πmkersubscript𝜋𝑚\mathrm{ker}\pi_{m} must be non-trivial. Note that A​(P3c)≅ℤ∗ℤ2𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐ℤsuperscriptℤ2A(P_{3}^{c})\cong\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}^{2} has no center. If ker​πm−1kersubscript𝜋𝑚1\mathrm{ker}\pi_{m-1} is non-trivial, then by Lemma 4.5, the defining graph P3csuperscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐P_{3}^{c} must have a full subgraph isomorphic to the cyclic graph of length 444, a contradiction. So we may assume that πm−1subscript𝜋𝑚1\pi_{m-1} is injective. In other words, A​(P3c)↪A1×⋯×Am−1↪𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐subscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝑚1A(P_{3}^{c})\hookrightarrow A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{m-1}. Hence, by repeating this argument, we can reduce the number of the direct factors in the target group. Finally, we have that A​(P3c)↪A1↪𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑃3𝑐subscript𝐴1A(P_{3}^{c})\hookrightarrow A_{1}, which is impossible. ∎

Lemma 4.7.

Let ΛΛ\Lambda be the join of the complements of finitely many path graphs and ΓΓ\Gamma a finite graph. Suppose that ψ:A​(Λ)→A​(Γ):𝜓→𝐴Λ𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\rightarrow A(\Gamma) is an embedding satisfying condition (KK). Then there is a full embedding ι:Λ→Γ:𝜄→ΛΓ\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(Λ)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄Λsupp𝜓\iota(\Lambda)\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi).

Proof.

Suppose that Λ1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} is the irreducible graphs such that Λ=Λ1∗⋯∗ΛmΛsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda=\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m} and Λi≅PnicsubscriptΛ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖𝑐\Lambda_{i}\cong P_{n_{i}}^{c} (1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m). Then by restricting ψ𝜓\psi to each direct factor A​(Λi)𝐴subscriptΛ𝑖A(\Lambda_{i}), we obtain ψ:A​(Λi)↪A​(Γ):𝜓↪𝐴subscriptΛ𝑖𝐴Γ\psi\colon A(\Lambda_{i})\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma) with condition (KK). Now by Lemma 4.2 and 4.6, we obtain full embeddings ιi:Λi→Γ:subscript𝜄𝑖→subscriptΛ𝑖Γ\iota_{i}\colon\Lambda_{i}\rightarrow\Gamma with ιi​(Λi)⊂supp​(ψi)subscript𝜄𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖suppsubscript𝜓𝑖\iota_{i}(\Lambda_{i})\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi_{i}) for (1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m). Since Λ1c,…,ΛmcsuperscriptsubscriptΛ1𝑐…superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑚𝑐\Lambda_{1}^{c},\ldots,\Lambda_{m}^{c} are path graphs, their connectedness together with Lemma 3.1 implies that Λ1,…,ΛmsubscriptΛ1…subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{m} are irreducible. Thus, by applying Proposition (2) to Λ=Λ1∗⋯∗ΛmΛsubscriptΛ1⋯subscriptΛ𝑚\Lambda=\Lambda_{1}*\cdots*\Lambda_{m}, we obtain the result that there is a full embedding ι:Λ→Γ:𝜄→ΛΓ\iota\colon\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma with ι​(Λ)⊂supp​(ψ)𝜄Λsupp𝜓\iota(\Lambda)\subset\mathrm{supp}(\psi). ∎

Proof of Theorem 1.3 (Theorem 4.1) .

Suppose that there is an embedding of the right-angled Artin group A​(Λ)𝐴ΛA(\Lambda) on the join ΛΛ\Lambda of the complements of finitely many path graphs into the right-angled Artin group A​(Γ)𝐴ΓA(\Gamma) on a finite graph ΓΓ\Gamma. By Theorem 2.3 due to Kim–Koberda, we have an embedding ψ:A​(Λ)↪A​(Γe):𝜓↪𝐴Λ𝐴superscriptΓ𝑒\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma^{e}) satisfying condition (KK), where ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e} is the extension graph of ΓΓ\Gamma. Consider the full subgraph Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime} of ΓesuperscriptΓ𝑒\Gamma^{e}, which is spanned by supp​(ψ)=∪v∈V​(Λ)supp​(ψ​(v))supp𝜓subscript𝑣𝑉Λsupp𝜓𝑣\mathrm{supp}(\psi)=\cup_{v\in V(\Lambda)}\mathrm{supp}(\psi(v)). Then we have an embedding ψ:A​(Λ)↪A​(Γ′):𝜓↪𝐴Λ𝐴superscriptΓ′\psi\colon A(\Lambda)\hookrightarrow A(\Gamma^{\prime}) satisfying condition (KK). Now, by Lemma 4.7, we have Λ≤Γ′ΛsuperscriptΓ′\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{\prime}. Thus Λ≤Γ′≤ΓeΛsuperscriptΓ′superscriptΓ𝑒\Lambda\leq\Gamma^{\prime}\leq\Gamma^{e}, as desired. ∎
